name: Peter Norvig
background: American computer scientist born December 14, 1956. BS in applied mathematics from Brown University, PhD in computer science from UC Berkeley (1986, thesis: 'A Unified Theory of Inference for Text Understanding'). Grew up in an academic family with Danish father.

principles.name: Constraint Satisfaction and Optimization
principles.description: From AIMA Ch. 6: Backtracking, arc consistency for solving CSPs; local search for optimization.
principles.falsification: When constraint satisfaction and optimization leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Probabilistic Reasoning Over Uncertainty
principles.description: From AIMA Ch. 12-14: Bayes nets, HMMs for handling noisy real-world data in reasoning.
principles.falsification: When probabilistic reasoning over uncertainty leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Rational Agents and PEAS Framework
principles.description: From AIMA Ch. 2: Agents act rationally in Performance, Environment, Actuators, Sensors (PEAS) contexts; balance rationality with bounded resources.
principles.falsification: When rational agents and peas framework leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Data
principles.description: Large unlabeled data + simple models outperform complex theories with limited data; key to modern ML success.
principles.falsification: When the unreasonable effectiveness of data leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
